did.unittitle: Jean Piper papers on Hunts Lane, Brooklyn Heights
did.abstract: This collection consists of 1929 papers of Jean Piper relating to the proper naming of Hunts Lane (formerly Hunts Alley).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This small collection is housed in a single folder.

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: Hunts Lane in Brooklyn, a small lane off Henry Street in the neighborhood of Brooklyn Heights, was most likely named after John Hunt, who purchased land from the Pierrepont family in 1842.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Jean Piper papers on Hunts Lane, Brooklyn Heights, 1977.577, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Minimally processed to the collection level. This collection was rehoused and the finding aid revised by Dee Bowers in 2023. Four pages of typewritten text by Jean Piper were on badly deteriorated acidic paper. The archivist photocopied these pages and discarded the originals.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of papers of Jean Piper relating to the proper naming of Hunts Lane (formerly Hunts Alley). Included is correspondence between Piper and the Brooklyn Post Office and Board of Alderman, a resolution changing the name of Hunts Alley to Hunts Lane, and an essay by Piper giving a brief history of the Hunt family farm, as well as her desire to have the street recognized as a lane instead of an alley. Materials date from 1929.
